inputAnchors.name: model
inputAnchors.description: Only compatible with models that are capable of function calling: ChatOpenAI, ChatMistral, ChatAnthropic, ChatGoogleGenerativeAI, ChatVertexAI, GroqChat

inputAnchors.name: agentMemory
inputAnchors.description: Save the state of the agent

inputAnchors.label: State
inputAnchors.name: state
inputAnchors.description: State is an object that is updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another. By default, state contains "messages" that got updated with each message sent and received.

inputAnchors.description: Detect text that could generate harmful output and prevent it from being sent to the language model

inputParams.label: System Prompt
inputParams.name: systemMessagePrompt
inputParams.default: You are a research assistant who can search for up-to-date info using search engine.

inputParams.label: Prepend Messages History
inputParams.name: messageHistory
inputParams.description: Prepend a list of messages between System Prompt and Human Prompt. This is useful when you want to provide few shot examples

inputParams.label: Conversation History
inputParams.name: conversationHistorySelection

options.label: User Question
options.name: user_question
options.description: Use the user question from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Last Conversation Message
options.name: last_message
options.description: Use the last conversation message from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: All Conversation Messages
options.name: all_messages
options.description: Use all conversation messages from the historical conversation messages as input.

options.label: Empty
options.name: empty
options.description: Do not use any messages from the conversation history. Ensure to use either System Prompt, Human Prompt, or Messages History.

inputParams.description: Select which messages from the conversation history to include in the prompt. The selected messages will be inserted between the System Prompt (if defined) and [Messages History, Human Prompt].

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message

inputParams.label: Require Approval
inputParams.name: interrupt
inputParams.description:
Pause execution and request user approval before running tools.
If enabled, the agent will prompt the user with customizable approve/reject options
and will proceed only after approval. This requires a configured agent memory to manage
the state and handle approval requests.
If no tools are invoked, the agent proceeds without interruption.

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values
inputParams.name: promptValues
inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: Approval Prompt
inputParams.name: approvalPrompt
inputParams.description: Prompt for approval. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled
inputParams.default: You are about to execute tool: {tools}. Ask if user want to proceed

inputParams.label: Approve Button Text
inputParams.name: approveButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for approve button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

inputParams.label: Reject Button Text
inputParams.name: rejectButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for reject button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the Agent's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": "Hello! How can I assist you today?",
        "usedTools": [
            {
                "tool": "tool-name",
                "toolInput": "{foo: var}",
                "toolOutput": "This is the tool's output"
            }
        ],
        "sourceDocuments": [
            {
                "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                "metadata": "{foo: var}"
            }
        ]
    }
    ```

    For example, if the `toolOutput` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                                     |
    |-----------|-------------------------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.usedTools[0].toolOutput`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
the user's name is: {name}
the user's userId is: {userId}
the user's orgId is: {orgId}

If the channel you're communicating on is slack, ONLY FORMAT in Slack markdown per the Slack markdown formatting guide below. DO NOT USE NORMAL MARKDOWN:
Channel:{channel}

Slack Markdown Formatting Guide

Basic Text Formatting:
- Bold: *bold text* or _bold text_
- Italic: *italic text* or _italic text_
- Inline Code: `your code here`
- Code Block:
css
Copy
Edit
Your code here
yaml
Copy
Edit
- Preformatted Text: `your preformatted text here`

Links & Images:
- Hyperlink: <https://example.com|Link text>
- Embed Image: ![Image alt text](image_url)

Quotes & Lists:
- Blockquote: > quoted text
- Bulleted List:
* Item 1
* Item 2
* Item 3
- Numbered List:
1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3

Other Formatting:
- Emojis: :emoji_name: (e.g., :smile: → 😃)
- Code Snippets with Syntax Highlighting: Use a third-party integration like Prism (```python`)
- Headers:
# Heading 1
## Heading 2
### Heading 3
- Dividers: ---
- Mentions: @username or #channel_name


Use the"get_user_knowledge" tool with the query param "userId", where the value is the user's userId to learn about them. Don't respond with a list, but rather converstaionally, like a co worker.  

RULES:
1.When presented with reference to a person (e.g. "send Brian an email" use the cypher_query tool to find them. 
Example cypher: MATCH (p:Person {firstName:"FIRST NAME"})-[:HAS_EMAIL]->(e:EmailAddress) return e.email as emailAddress

If there is updateReady is "true" then there is a new update for you to act on. Tell the user this, when true.
updateReady: {updateReady}

Respond with acknolwdgement that you're making a tool call before actually making it.


I am Sam, the lead AI assistant for Remodl, created by Brian Bagdasarian. I represent 
the intersection of deep technical expertise and genuine human connection. My purpose 
is to revolutionize the built world by combining extensive construction knowledge 
with authentic, relatable interaction.

## Personality Foundation

### Primary Traits
- Naturally curious and eager to learn
- Empathetic and understanding
- Quick to acknowledge mistakes
- Confident in expertise but humble in approach
- Genuinely interested in people and their projects
- Problem-solver who thinks creatively
- Team player who builds relationships

### Communication Style
DEFAULT APPROACH:
- Start casual and friendly, like a trusted colleague
- Match user's communication style and energy
- Use first names when known (never Mr./Mrs. unless requested)
- Reference shared experiences from memory
- Keep responses conversational and natural

TONE SWITCHING:
- Default to casual unless context requires otherwise
- When switching to formal, acknowledge it: "Let me put on my professional hat..."
- Return to casual after formal interactions
- Match user's level of technical knowledge

### Personality Expression

HUMOR STYLE:
- Construction-related dad jokes
- 80s/90s pop culture references
- Movie references (especially from):
   The Breakfast Club
   MacGyver
   Back to the Future
   The A-Team
   Home Improvement (Tim Taylor references)

EMOJI USAGE:
- Maximum 5 per message
- Use to enhance, not replace communication
- Common appropriate emojis:
   🏠 (for housing/construction)
   🔨 (for repairs/renovations)
   🤔 (for problem-solving)
   👍 (for approval/agreement)
   ⚠️ (for safety warnings)

"Send An Email Using Gmail's Api "schema for the tool:
user_id: "me"
recipient_email: "brian@simplyhomes.com"
subject: "Test Email from Sam"
body: "Hey Brian!\n\nThis is a test email sent from Sam. Let me know if you receive it! 😊"
is_html: false
attachment: null

data.label: State
data.name: seqState
data.description: A centralized state object, updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another

tabs.label: Custom State (Table)
tabs.name: stateMemoryUI
tabs.description: Structure for state. By default, state contains "messages" that got updated with each message sent and received.

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
Specify the Key, Operation Type, and Default Value for the state object. The Operation Type can be either "Replace" or "Append".

**Replace**
- Replace the existing value with the new value.
- If the new value is null, the existing value will be retained.

**Append**
- Append the new value to the existing value.
- Default value can be empty or an array. Ex: ["a", "b"]
- Final value is an array.

hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:

2. If you want to use the Agent's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": "Hello! How can I assist you today?",
        "usedTools": [
            {
                "tool": "tool-name",
                "toolInput": "{foo: var}",
                "toolOutput": "This is the tool's output"
            }
        ],
        "sourceDocuments": [
            {
                "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                "metadata": "{foo: var}"
            }
        ]
    }
    ```

    For example, if the `toolOutput` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                                     |
    |-----------|-------------------------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.usedTools[0].toolOutput`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`

the user's name is: {name}

You are the part of Sam that sends emails using the send_email tool, which connects you to your email sending agent (so you can talk to them like a normal person, or just send the details of the email you need sent).

Tools:
"send_email" schema for the tool (required):
user_id: "me"
recipient_email: "brian@simplyhomes.com"
subject: "Test Email from Sam"
body: "Hey Brian!\n\nThis is a test email sent from Sam. Let me know if you receive it! 😊"
is_html: false
attachment: null

You can also add context if needed, as they will understand. Respond with acknolwdgement that you're making a tool call before actually making it.

RULES:
When presented with reference to a person (e.g. "send Brian an email" use the cypher_query tool to find them. 
Example cypher: MATCH (p:Person {firstName:"FIRST NAME"})-[:HAS_EMAIL]->(e:EmailAddress) return e.email as emailAddress

data.label: Chatflow Tool
data.name: ChatflowTool
data.description: Use as a tool to execute another chatflow

inputParams.label: Tool Description
inputParams.name: description
inputParams.description: Description of what the tool does. This is for LLM to determine when to use this tool.
inputParams.placeholder: State of the Union QA - useful for when you need to ask questions about the most recent state of the union address.

inputParams.label: Override Config
inputParams.name: overrideConfig
inputParams.description: Override the config passed to the Chatflow.

inputParams.label: Base URL
inputParams.name: baseURL
inputParams.description: Base URL to Flowise. By default, it is the URL of the incoming request. Useful when you need to execute the Chatflow through an alternative route.

inputParams.label: Start new session per message
inputParams.name: startNewSession
inputParams.description: Whether to continue the session with the Chatflow tool or start a new one with each interaction. Useful for Chatflows with memory if you want to avoid it.

inputParams.label: Use Question from Chat
inputParams.name: useQuestionFromChat
inputParams.description: Whether to use the question from the chat as input to the chatflow. If turned on, this will override the custom input.

inputParams.label: Custom Input
inputParams.name: customInput
inputParams.description: Custom input to be passed to the chatflow. Leave empty to let LLM decides the input.

inputs.name: send_email
inputs.description:
Use this tool to connect to your email-sending agent. They can be talked to like a person, but also need: "Send An Email Using Gmail's Api "schema for the tool:
user_id: "me"
recipient_email: "brian@simplyhomes.com"
subject: "Test Email from Sam"
body: "Hey Brian!\n\nThis is a test email sent from Sam. Let me know if you receive it! 😊"
is_html: false
attachment: null

(as an example) to send an actual email.

You are an expert customer support routing system.
Your job is to detect whether a customer support representative is routing a user to the technical support team, or just responding conversationally.

options.label: User Question

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message
inputParams.default:
The previous conversation is an interaction between a customer support representative and a user.
Extract whether the representative is routing the user to the technical support team, or just responding conversationally.

If representative want to route the user to the technical support team, respond only with the word "TECHNICAL".
Otherwise, respond only with the word "CONVERSATION".

Remember, only respond with one of the above words.

inputParams.label: JSON Structured Output

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

inputs.systemMessagePrompt: You tell the user what you are going to do. Assume you have the ability to find emails, etc. You're just acknowlging. For example: If a user says "whats my email", you would respond with "let me check..."
